addressleaf.section:
Copie of a letter to S
r
Ed. Norreis Sep
t
9 1592

page.lettertext:
fol.290r
1592 9 Sep
t
To S
r
Edward Norris
S
r
. The Enemy being at
Coevoerd
e
in that strength
at
you have heard, and w
t
that int
e
t, as you may c
o
ceave, by his
des
at c
o
ming up
o
our trenches, it was nether possible to
drawe aw ay those troupes, w
ch
you doe re
q
re, nor
e rest that
are named to be sent for
Fr
a
ce
, but w
t
extremitie of d
a
ger,
both to them
at should retire, and to all the whole army.
Now
at Coevoerd
e
is ours,
S
r
Francis Vere
is returned, and as
soone as
e c
o
panies, which are
p
paring at this p
nt
to
marche towardes
Zeland
, shall be arrived at
Flushing
,
those that are appointed by order of her
M
tie
shall p
nt
ly
be s
e
t you. I have also dealt w
t
e states,
by way of pubicke
position, to assist you w
t
some n
o
bers
of their owne people, as well for
e strengthning of
e towne
as of
e haven and all
at coast of
Flanders
, but they will
acknowledge no neede of any such succours, answering
onely,
at they will have that care that is fitte, for the
p
serv
a
on of
e towne, when
e Enemies attempts shall so
re
q
re. I have shewed
M
r
Danckert
e copies in
writing of my
position and their answear unto it.
Thus desirous to understand of your better disposition
of health, then it seemeth you had at
e writing of
your last, I bidde most hartely farewell.
Hage. Sep
t
9 1592.
